_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Velsicol Chemical Corporation's Memphis Tennessee plant has prepared this Risk Management Plan (RMP) in accordance with the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) regulations under the federal Clean Air Act.  The elements of this RMP, dealing with the safe handling and management of chemicals, have been in place and in practice at the plant for many years.


The RMP Submit software does not provide the flexibility to input a series of dates relative to completion of the program elements.  Because Process Hazards Analyses and other tasks outlined in the plan generally occur over several days,  the program default value of the first day of the month was selected to reflect completion of the task within the month and year indicated by the inputted date. 


Policies and procedures regarding the prevention of accidental releases, as well as those describing how we respond to accidental releases and other types of potential emergencies, are well established at the plant.  These are described in detail in the Plant Emergency Control Plan. 


The chemical substances handled at the plant addressed in this RMP (i.e. "Regulated Substances") are Chlorine and Hydrazine.  Velsicol has no flammable chemicals covered by the rule.  The areas in the plant where these two chemicals are handled in the largest quantities (i.e"Covered Processes"as defined in 40 CFR 68.3) are:

1.  One or two 90 ton Chlorine railcars located at the chlorine unloading area on the east (Warford St.) side of the plant and the associated 9 ton chlorine storage tanks.
2.  One 4500 gallon storage tank of Hydrazine adjacent to the chlorine unloading area in the central part of the plant.

For these specific regulated substances,  the rule requires that a single worst-case release scenario analysis be prepared.  It further requires preparation of an alternative release scenario for each of these substances.

The "worst-case release scenario" for purposes of this RMP is described as an instantan

velopment of process safety procedures, and full access to all information required under RMP.

Over the past five years, the plant has had no accidental releases from processes covered in this RMP that resulted in deaths, injuries, lost time or OSHA recordable injuries, or significant property damage on or off the plant site.

In the event of an accidental release, the plant would activate its Emergency Control Plan.  This plan specifies actions to be taken in response to any release.  The plan includes procedures for making notifications to parties outside the plant and is fully coordinated with the local Emergency Management Agency's plan.

The plant continuously strives to improve the safety of its operations through its Responsible Care Leadership Team which meets on a regular basis.
